Received
July 14th 1921
Baghdad
May
5
1921
? June
Darling Parents . I'm answering your letters of May 4 - I may say
incidentally that your weekly letters are the greatest joy. I don't know
what I should do without them. Mother's was full of the
Ross
Smith
flight Ross Smith was an Australian aviator who, with his brother Keith, were the first pilots to fly fom England to Australia in 1919. He was a pilot for TE Lawrence, and made pioneering flights from Cairo to Calcutta, and Calcutta to Timor. It is unclear which flight this letter refers to, or it may even mean a documentary 'The Ross Smith Flight,' released in 1921.
, which indeed sounds wonderful - I wish I had been
there. And yours, Father , told of the very interesting
Rly
Railway Likely refers to 1921 Railways Act, grouping railways into amalgamated regional lines.
arrangements +
of the appeal of the Steel Smelters Association - isn't it incredible! You
speak of there being a good deal of distress, + that's a month ago
I wonder what it can be like now?
We are not having a very easy time. Persia is a doubtful quantity
but so far remains quiescent. The man who has been put in in Saiyid
Zia 's place - Quwam al Saltanah - is a capable person, Sir Percy
says. He represents the Liberal aristocracy, but whether any
aristocracy will be Liberal enough to put up a case against
Bolshevism is what I doubt. Armitage Smith is holding on for the
moment but it's to my mind ominous that the excellent military
adviser, Col. Huddlestone , talks of coming away as he can now
do nothing. If he decides to go I hope we may get him here
to run the Levies in the place of Ironside . (By the way Gen.
Ironside left Basrah on the 26th they stuck on the bar
till June 2 + then returned to Basrah for coal. Il n'a pas de
chance - every means of conveyance breaks down under him.)
Saiyid Zia is here on his way to India + England . England
seems to be the refuge of discharged Nationalists - first Faisal
+ then Saiyid Zia! It's rather comic, when you come to think of it,
that the Imperialist Tyranny which the Bolshevists denounce all
over Asia should gather under the shadow of its wings every patriot
who is out of a job. Saiyid Zia is a very interesting man. He
lunched one day with the Coxes (I had met him in Tehran )
+ dined next day with me to meet Ja'far whose acquaintance
he wanted to make. We talked Persian + French. He attributes his
fall Tabataba’i was an Iranian journalist and pro-Constitution politician who spearheaded the 1921 Persian coup d'état and aimed to reform Qajar rule. He was appointed Prime Minister in February 1921 but was asked to resign and leave the country on 23rd May 1921.
entirely to the machinations of the Shah who feared his
projects of social reform + was determined to displace him.
I don't want Persia to lapse into a Bolshevist chaos but it will
make me laugh to see the Shah engulfed in it.

Well that's that. In Angora , I think I told you, the extremists have
got the upper hand which from our point of view means that Turkish
agitation continues on our northern frontier. The last incident is
that a Turkish officer + 13 men have appeared at Rawandaz
a Kurdish town in the mountains
W. West
of Mosul . The greater part
of the town had just sent in a petition that they might be allowed
to come into the 'Iraq state under our mandate, but the appearance
of this Turkish reconnaissance has sent a shiver, or a thrill as
the case may be, all down the Kurdish frontier which is waiting to
see whether more Turks are to follow + what the English will
do. As you know, we haven't got a military margin to defend
the frontier against Turkish aggression; the assumption at
Cairo The 1921 Cairo Conference was a series of meetings held by British officials with the aim of reshaping British foreign policy in the Middle East after the First World War and the fall of the Ottoman Empire.
was
that we were to be at peace with Turkey
My young Nationalist friends are alarmed at the activity of the
Turks on the frontier + the existence of a large body of pro-
Turkish feeling in this country . Their feeling is that the return of
the Turks would kill or indefinitely postpone their dearest
hopes - namely the setting up of an independent Arab state.
This is the sentiment which we want to foster, + as it is
held exclusively by Sharifians, they are the people for us to
back, as we decided at Cairo. Unfortunately there have been
many (mostly unavoidable) delays + Faisal who should have
been here in the middle of May has not yet left Mecca . The
League of Nations is holding up the Mandate in deference to
American prejudices (this is deeply secret) + Mr Churchill ' s
statement in the House A statement by Winston Churchill, which eventually took place on the 14th of June 1921, in which he announced the outcomes of the Cairo Conference, specifically relating to the support of Feisal by the British to become the first monarch of Iraq.
which ought to have taken place
on June 2 is again postponed. Sir Percy has urged that
we should drop the mandate altogether + go for a treaty
with the Arab state when it is constituted. It would be a
magnificent move if we're bold enough to do it. It isn't the
mandate which bothers us here - no Nationalist wants to
shake loose from British help + control; but the word Mandate
isn't popular + a freely negotiated treaty would be
infinitely better liked, besides giving us a much freer hand.

2
We have always known that Faisal would ultimately insist on a
treaty in place of a mandate - now we have the opportunity
of making a beau geste + giving of our own accord what we
should certainly have had to give later at his request.
Meantime
the amnesty Amnesty granted by the British to pardon those involved in the 1920 Iraqi Revolt against the British.
is out + my friends are busying
themselves in the constitution of a moderate
Sharifian party Term referring to things related to the Sharif (a title used to describe those - usually royal - claiming descent from the prophet Muhammad), in this case, politicians organised under Faisal, the Sharif.
with a definite programme - the latter was submitted
to me. Their difficulties are set forth in the enclosed very
confidential note, but Sir Percy has told them (through me)
to go ahead + rely on his support. By the way you'll
notice that I'm not at Sulaimani . When I told Naji +
Nuri that I thought of going away for a week their faces
fell so definitely that I said I would reconsider it. I consulted
with Sir Percy + we decided I had better not be away at
this juncture. I was sorry, but I don 't really mind much
because I like to be able to help them. I had told Haji Naji
- who is an ardent Sharifian - that I was going + he sent
me an urgent message begging me to come + see him before
I went. I went down that evening to see him. "I sent for
you" said he "because I don 't want you to go away now."
"Well I'm not young "said I. "Praise be to God" he returned.
"You see the
High Commissioner Sir Percy Cox
is like God Almight + you're
the Nabi Isa (the Prophet Jesus). How is he to know what
is going on the world if you' re not there?"
One of the difficulties is Mr Philby . He has a strong prejudice
against Faisal + as he is running the Ministry of the Interior
he is in a position to make a passive resistance of a
very effective kind. We can't get a Nationalist paper started
because it has to be registered in the Interior + all kinds
of legal quibbles are invented to delay it. In the same
way under Turkish law (which is ours) a political party
has to be registered by that ministry + we anticipate that
similar delays will occur. However Sir Percy is now

warned + he will take steps to facilitate matters. It is
very provoking about Mr Philby ; it seems most unnecessary
that your official policy should be in any way hindered by
one of your own officials. He never comes to see me so I suppose
he looks on me as the arch enemy - or not far from it.
And I can't give him a friendly word of warning. But he is
spinning a bad cotton for he is earning a name as an
opponent + I should not be at all surprised if Faisal ,
when he gets into the saddle, asks for his removal.
I'm very sorry, but I've done my best to make a bridge + if he
won't walk over it I can't help him.
Captain Smith + I (you know he's the son of the Master of
Baliol ) went to another school function this week. It
was a prodigious affair. Le tout Baghdad was there - the
Arab world, we were the only English - + it lasted the usual
3 hours. We sat in rows + listened to speeches, songs + poems.
+ I really believe the audience liked it. It's a great
mistake to think that what bores one sort of people will
bore another. There were parts of it which were quite
remarkably boring, long speeches (no speech lasted less
than 15 minutes) about the light of education being the
sole ray that illumines the world; but I must confess
that there were also interesting moments. One was an ode
by our half paralyzed old poet, Jamil Zahawi - there were
35 moments of it, which was is long for an ode, but
nevertheless it was worth sitting through. He is not
only a great poet but he is a very great diseur . He
began by tumbling off the estrade + having to be poked +
pushed back onto it while everyone murmured "Allah!"
Then he embarked on an invocation of some 20 couplets
to the skies of the 'Iraq . He began very quietly with great

3
throbbing lines which pulsed on to a growing volume of sound.
The whole audience took fire, they bent forward, with their
faces illuminated + time after time the falling couplet
was revived with a "Repeat! repeat!" Ja'far, who cares
very much for poetry, was sitting behind me. I looked round
+ saw his face alight with excitement. But they all
cared; they were a really sympathetic audience - even
when the poem wandered off into sloughs of
dullness dulness
in
which we were told in verse of the distance between
the sun + the earth + other matters not suited to odes.
Jamil Zahawi was followed by another + rival poet,
a man called Ma'ruf who has just returned from
Palestine - he came back with us on the Hardinge .
He is said to be one of the greatest Arabists living. I did
n't understand the poem which was immensely
applauded, but I did understand the speech with which
he prefaced it + I thought it first rate, very bold
+ liberal + full of good sense. He condemned
the ancient methods of Islamic education root +
branch + I thought I noticed some of my
turbaned turbanned
.
neighbours drawing their robes metaphorically round
them. Quite a number of little boys made set speeches
also. They weren't the least embarrassed as our little
boys would have been; except for their squeaking rats'
voices they débitéd their platitudes just as unctuously
as their elders. The smallest of all - he was lifted onto
a chair to address us - started away at the top of his
voice but in the middle of the speech, the voice entirely.
disappeared. He went on playing the orator but making
no sound at all, till someone obligingly lifted him
off the chair + he vanished from sight. He may be declaiming

soundlessly to this day for ought I know.
We all had to get up at 5 next morning to go to the King 's
Birthday Parade which was held in the desert quite near my
house. All the Arab magnates came + there were an
astonishing number of troops, but this was a deception
- we happened to have in Baghdad the regiments
which have just come down from Persia + are going to
India or England . It ended with a flight of 30
aeroplanes which really was splendid. The Coxes
gave a dinner that night - C. in C. + staff, French, American
+ Persian consuls Ja'far + Sasun Eff , the Garbetts
+ me. It was very well done. After dinner we sat
on the terrace over the river. The trees were heavy
with coloured lights + the lights of the town glittered
across the river. It's a great asset having your
river running through the heart of your city.
I rode for 2 hours this morning before breakfast
- it's not even now a bit hot; we've once
had it up to 109 but only once. Col. Joyce
is coming to dine + have a good talk
about things in general.
Ever your very affectionate daughter
Gertrude.
